entry.title: The Mutated Next Year Page
entry.content:
समाधिBot: Boop.

India: Okay, this is the mutated next year page.

समाधिBot: Oh wow!

India: This is Taji…

समाधिBot: Uh huh… Taji looks like a demonic bug.

India: Yes. This is Zahra.

समाधिBot: She looks like a mosquito.

India: She kind of is a mosquito.

समाधिBot: Okay, is Miles on here?

India: Yeah Miles is that mosquito.

समाधिBot: How do you feel about that, Miles?

Miles: Not that good.

India: And there’s Woobie. He’s a man-eating barker dog.

Miles: I’m just happy that I’m not that guy.

समाधिBot: You’re happy that you’re not Taj?

India: He looks kind of like a mutated potato.

समाधिBot: Alright let’s be nice to mutated-potato-Taj.

India: This is me, and that’s daddy.

समाधिBot: Dad looks terrifyingly happy. What am I so happy about? That I didn’t have to be a mosquito? Is mom on here?

India: She’s that guy… lady.

समाधिBot: Lady, yeah. And then there’s the sun…

India: Yeah that’s Uncle David.

समाधिBot: That’s Uncle David! And what’s up here?

India: That’s the moon. He’s smiling in the background.

समाधिBot: And what about these orbs back there?

India: Well, they’re mad. They’re chasing him, but he doesn’t notice. Because he’s going around in circles. He’s pacing…

समाधिBot: What are these though?

India: They’re little stars.

समाधिBot: They’re stars chasing the moon?

India: Mmm-hmm.

Miles: But stars are millions of times bigger than any normal sized moon… usually…

समाधिBot: “That's no moon. It's a space station.”

India: Mmm uh-kay…

समाधिBot: What is this writing all about?

India: Well, I just put that there for the fun of it.

समाधिBot: Yeah? Your hand writing is pretty good. “Skamizzic skitpwit to you eeskt.”

Miles: What’s this guy saying?

समाधिBot: “Meat kips.”

Miles: Taj is saying, “Eh tissuah… Ketita.”

India: Anyway, that’s someone else’s fridge, and Woobie’s totally scavenging off everything except for half of a bone.

समाधिBot: Ha! And he’s looking back at that half bone, thinking, “Maybe I’d like to go back for some more.”

India: Okay, the other side…

India: These are a bunch of guys that have been filled up with blood.

समाधिBot: Oh yeah? Aren’t all guys kind of filled up with blood?

India: Um, yes, but these guys really like being like that, so they just kind of turned red.

समाधिBot: And tell me about the heart.

India: Yeah… I let Taj draw this part. I drew this for Taji so that he could give it to you.

समाधिBot: What about this part?

India: That’s Taj and that’s bald you.

समाधिBot: That’s bald me?

India: Actually bald Taji and hairy you.

समाधिBot: I think hairy Taj and bald me is closer to the truth.

Miles: You’re so creepy daddy.

समाधिBot: In real life, or in this drawing?

Miles: In that drawing. You’re a weirdo without a beard-o.

India: You’ve got giant eyes…

समाधिBot: I like that heart.

India: Yeah Taji decorated it a lot.

समाधिBot: Taj decorated that? I like his decorations.

India: Speaking of Taj, did you make mommy coffee?

समाधिBot: No, ‘cos she’s not awake yet. What does Taj have to do with coffee?

entry.title: Hut Hay Hen Hike
entry.content:
India: We’re doing an interview on the letter ‘H’. I know one thing about it: it’s respectable to feed animals.

समाधिBot: Oh yeah?

India: Mmm-hmm. Well, if you’ve got an animal, and you never feed it, that’s not good to do. Another thing is, if you see a stranger, you’re really not a'sposed to mess with it…

Taj: What — what did you say?

India: Well you’re not really supposed to mess with anybody if they’re a stranger.

समाधिBot: Yeah… wait… mess with their mind??

India: No, you know, talk to them.

समाधिBot: Oh, okay… right… um… okay. Taji, what’s in the picture? Can you see a letter ‘H’?

India: I can!

Taj: Yes, I can. It’s on the house.

समाधिBot: What color is the ‘H’?

India & Taj: White.

India: The chicken matches the color of the ‘H’. Another thing: the door looks like a pancake.

समाधिBot: It’s a pancake door!

India: But another thing about it: the girls did a good job. Usually you’re supposed to leave when you see a stranger, but instead they made a meal for him —

Taj: Hey daddy you did awesome trees.

समाधिBot: Thanks, Taj! India, do you want to tell the story behind this picture? You don’t have to tell the whole story, but tell generally what happened. I know that there was a hut, and there were three girls, and a creepy stranger, but I don’t know all of what happened.

India: I know one part of it. It’s kind of the end part. The girls all went to sleep, except the wise one, which kind of thought, “Oh! I have to feed the animals!” The other girls, they just went to sleep, and old stranger dude locked them in the cellar.

समाधिBot: Dear me…

India: But the girl who fed the animals, it’s kind of like a thing. You know, like a test? When you get a punishment for not doing something. Well why didn’t he tell them?

समाधिBot: Why indeed!

India: Another thing: there’s something kind of suspecting about the fire. Not everyone who just lives in the middle of nowhere knows how to light a fire. So maybe he knew how to make food… but the girls just kind of did it.

समाधिBot: Yeah… if you know how to make a fire, presumably you could make at least something simple enough to —

India: Like an egg —

समाधिBot: Like an egg. Something simple enough to feed the animals.

India: And the chicken — Taj, stop messing with the door.

समाधिBot: Are you gonna split, Taj?

Taj: Mommy said it’s lunch time.

India: The ‘H’ looks good because the chimney. In one part of the ‘H’ it goes up through the roof to the chimney. I thought the rest of the ‘H’ was just going to go up out of the chimney. And this background part is like a Christmas tree —

Taj: Hey guys it’s time to have lunch.

India: Dinner.

समाधिBot: Dinner.

India: Anyway that looks like Christmas has already gone past. And he had a Christmas tree but then he planted it somewhere.

समाधिBot: True dat.

India: And the roof looks like hay.

समाधिBot: Yep. And he’s having a fire inside his hut with a straw roof, which I don’t think I would do, but I guess in Scandinavian countries they do that. Seems dodgy to me.

entry.title: Small Eyed Sphinx Moth
entry.content:
समाधिBot: What is it?

Miles: Small eyed sphinx.

समाधिBot: And where did you find it?

India: Back porch? It was just sitting on one of the stairs.

Miles: Ohh! That was a cocoon that I hatched!

India: Wow!

समाधिBot: Where’d you find the —

India: — cocoon?

Miles: I didn’t find the cocoon.

India: You found the egg?

Miles: No.

समाधिBot & India: You found the caterpillar?

Miles: No.

India: Then what —

समाधिBot: — did you find?

Miles: I found a moth, and it laid eggs, and then they hatched into caterpillars, and then they formed cocoons, and then there were moths. I released all of them but this one.

समाधिBot: Crazy… wow… you’re kind of a mother.

समाधिBot: When did you find this moth’s mother?

Miles: Last year.

समाधिBot: Where did you find her?

Miles: I was walking in the woods, and then it fell on my head.

समाधिBot: It fell on your head?!

Miles: Yes.

समाधिBot: This moth’s own mother fell on your head? Wow…

India: I’ve got a question: why does it have a waggly tail?

Miles: That subspecies of sphinx moths usually have curved tails. And its underwings stick out beyond its top wings.

समाधिBot: Do these fly well?

Miles: Yes, almost all sphinx moths are really strong flyers.

समाधिBot: Its body looks so big in comparison to its wings, it seems like it would have a hard time flying.

Miles: Someone found a pink spotted sphinx twenty miles off the coast of Georgia… yes I think it was Georgia… yes. It flew out to sea twenty-five miles.

समाधिBot: Wow, they found it on their boat, or they found it on an island?

Miles: It landed on their boat.

India: You know those brown and pink things? At the side of its wings? What are they?

Miles: That’s the side of its wings.

India: I know, that’s what I’m talking about. What are they?

Miles: The side of its wings! The side of its wings are the side of its wings.

India: Okay… the side of its wings are the side of its wings…

Miles: That red line on it looks almost like a mohawk. See its underwings stick out? That particular species usually does that.

India: Those things… those pink and brown things.

Miles: Those are just pigments in its wings. You’re talking complete nonsense, India.

entry.title: What is not to like about Wasps, Mosquitos and Yellow Jackets?
entry.content:
समाधिBot: What’s this one?

India: It’s about how much I do not like wasps, mosquitos and yellow jackets.

समाधिBot: What is not to like about wasps, mosquitos and yellow jackets?

India: Well, sometimes when you’re swimming and yellow jackets fall in the water, they sting you just to hold on, instead of grabbing on. And that’s what happened to me.

समाधिBot: You got stung in the water by a yellow jacket?

India: Yep. That’s why I don’t like yellow jackets.

समाधिBot: You know, I don’t think they do it to hold on. I think they do it just to be mean.

India: Yeah. The reason why I don’t like wasps is because one stung Miles. And when you’re minding your own business, sitting down or standing up, they just sting you for no reason.

समाधिBot: I got stung by a dead wasp when I was little. Could you imagine stinging someone after you’re already dead?

India: No… The reason why I don’t like mosquitos is because you’re always minding your business when you get bitten by one.

समाधिBot: Is that one half full or half empty?

India: Half full.

समाधिBot: Half full of blood?

India: Yeah, I could only draw the thing like that because… well you know.

entry.title: Katydid
entry.content:
समाधिBot: A katydid is a five-legged insect that’s kind of like a grasshopper —

Miles: It’s six-legged, that one just lost its leg. Sometimes their back legs fall off.

समाधिBot: Why would their back legs fall off?

Miles: I don’t know, they’re just not attached that well.

India: They do it for defense, like if a wasp egg was clinging on it, you know —

Miles: Uhh, no they don’t, they don’t really do it for defense —

India: You know how those sea star things —

Miles: No, it’s not like that. They sometimes get their leg snagged… and then their leg falls off.

India: And they’re not injured at all…

समाधिBot: What do these guys eat?

Miles: Leaves.

समाधिBot: Leaves exclusively? They wouldn’t eat an aphid if one came along?

Miles: Grass… things like that. Things like grasshoppers eat, they seem to have a grasshopper diet. Except they seem to like leaves more. And sometimes they bite people.

समाधिBot: Really? So they would eat an aphid?

Miles: Yeah maybe. And look, they have tiny little antennae right there… and there… [pointing to the sides of its mouth]

India: Is it like a Komodo dragon that smells with its tongue?

Miles: No.

India: So it smells with its nose?

समाधिBot: It also has a weird plate-like thing on the tip of its nose.

Miles: This is what it does… [gestures]

समाधिBot: Oh that’s its upper lip? What’s behind that?

Miles: Underneath there’s… how am I gonna do this… [makes sideways chewing gestures]

समाधिBot: Ah!

Miles: Like that… mandibles. And it looks just like a leaf. Its wings look just like a leaf. They even have veins to go with it.

Taj: Hey guys let’s just delete this one. This one isn’t good. This interview isn’t good —

समाधिBot: It’s never too late! Things can always turn around —

Taj: How much more minutes? How much more minutes?

समाधिBot: Um… we don’t know. You never know how long an interview is gonna go. But I edit heavily…

Miles: So we get out all of the poo talk —

समाधिBot: Yes, any mention of poo gets removed.

India: I know one thing about them: they’re like praying mantises, they lick their legs all the time. And if you look closely at the skin it looks like jelly.

समाधिBot: It looks like bubbly green candy jelly.

Taj: And someone might want to eat this one.

समाधिBot: Oh yeah, and its little hand! It’s got a hook at the end, what does it do with its hook?

Miles: I think it just sits around with it.

entry.title: You Say sɪˈkeɪdə and I’ll Say sɪˈkɑːdə
entry.content:
समाधिBot: What do you know about cicadas?

India: Miles, what do you know about cicadas?

Miles: What do you know about cicadas?

India: They make ear splitting sounds?

समाधिBot: Why do they do that?

India: I dunno, to attract a mate or something?

समाधिBot: Is it a female trying to attract a male, or a male trying to attract a female?

India: I guess a male?

Miles: They usually make the earsplitting noises while they’re eating. I don’t know why, but they drink sap at the same time.

Taj: India doesn’t know about any cicadas.

India: And they’ve got giant eyeballs.

समाधिBot: Can they see well?

Miles: They have pretty good eyesight. They’re not like a dragonfly or a mantis shrimp. Mantis shrimps can see about seventeen times better than humans.

समाधिBot: Really?!! Mantis shrimps?

Miles: Yes. They also sit in holes, and when divers poke at them they smash off their fingers.

समाधिBot: Good lawd!

Miles: They don’t bite them off, it’s just the force of it, they go like that [gestures] and their pincer travels out at about 500 miles per hour.

समाधिBot: Do these guys have a mouth?

Miles: No, they have a little sucky thing squished against their neck, and then they up-stretch it and stab it into a tree, and suck its blood, basically.

समाधिBot: Could they do that to a person?

Miles: No.

समाधिBot: Are you sure? I was a little freaked out by this little guy when I was taking his picture. ‘These any relation to a locust?

Miles: I don’t really know, but I’m pretty sure that they’re basically a giant spittle bug.

समाधिBot: Don’t those spittle bugs have a seventh appendage —

Miles: A gear. A naturally forming gear.

समाधिBot: A naturally forming gear — am I thinking of a spittle bug?

Miles: Yes.

समाधिBot: These don’t have anything like that.

Miles: Yes but they do fly in much the same way. And they have the same sort of shape.

समाधिBot: They have kind of like a hammerhead shark head.

Miles: Yeah, and they look like they have mustaches.

समाधिBot: Do they have a mustache?

Miles: Mmm, I dunno, I think it’s just antennae right below their nose and their mouth.

India: Have you seen how the head looks kind of like a hammerhead shark’s head?

Miles: Yeah we were just talking about that. And right at the bottom of the wings they’re bright green.

समाधिBot: Where do cicadas overwinter? Are they eggs then? Are they grubs?

Miles: I’m not really sure. The ones that come out every seventeen years —

समाधिBot: Isn’t that locusts?

Miles: No cicadas, it’s a variety of cicada. Those ones grow insanely slowly.

समाधिBot: And they’re underground for all that time, right?

Miles: Mmm-hmm.
